Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 China Graphical abstract Mn-doped spinel oxides CoAl2O4 marked as CMA-m (m = Co/Mn atom ratio) herein were synthesized and evaluated for the first time as supports of Co-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts. HAADF-STEM images showed that Mn doping caused more crystal defects on the surface of CMA-m grains, which may provide more attachment sites for cobalt loading, leading to much smaller Co0 particle size of 15Co/CMA-m than that of 15Co/CoAl2O4. Data of H2/CO chemisorption showed that the interaction of highly dispersed Co0 with lattice Mn-doped CMA-m grain has a promotive effect on CO adsorption capability. FTS evaluation results demonstrate that 15Co/CMA-20 showed the highest CO conversion, C5+ selectivity and C5+ STY, benefiting from its high Co0 dispersion and CO chemisorption capability as a result of suitable Mn doping into the lattice of CoAl2O4, which was confirmed very different from the influence of impregnated Mn oxide over CoAl2O4. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Lattice Mn doping CoAl2O4 spinel Dispersion Lattice defects 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) has been exploited as an alternative non-petroleum route of synthesizing clean liquid fuels and high valued-added chemicals from syngas derived from coal, natural gas or biomass [1–3]. But the scale of exploitation and utilization of fossil energy will be more and more limited, and gradually shrink, to achieve the goal of carbon neutrality, so the conversion of biomass based syngas through FTS might become one of the most important eco-friendly route in the future, to produce C5+ paraffins as clean fuels, high value-added chemicals such as clean solvent oil and wax [4,5], and the latter is widely used as feed for production of high grade lube. Many researches focus on improving activity, C5+ selectivity as well as stability of FTS catalyst [6–10]. Spinels have been investigated as efficient catalyst supports for FTS reaction [11–13]. According to our former work [11], CoAl2O4 synthesized by sol-gel method performs more active and C5+ selective than Al2O3 when used as support for Co based FTS catalyst, but the dispersion degree of Co loaded on CoAl2O4 is low and remains to be improved to obtain a higher use efficiency of Co, and a better performance of the catalyst for syngas conversion to C5+ paraffins. Research reports have proved that the lattice defects on the surface of the support can provide more attachment sites, which is beneficial to improve the dispersion of loaded metal, and further affect the performance of catalysts [14]. However, there are few reports on the influence of supports defects on catalyst performance for FTS reactions. Element doping of spinel can form defects on the surface of lattice and tune the properties of spinels [15–18]. Peng, et al. [19] doped phosphorus to a manganese-cobalt oxide (MCO) spinel via plasma treatment in the presence of NaH2PO2, and produce defects on the spinel. Spinel oxides Co1-xMnxAl2O4 (x = 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3) have been investigated by prof. Pradhan et al. as optical and magnetic materials [20]. They used a conventional solid-state-reaction procedure to prepare the materials, and obtained polycrystalline spinels. Sinha et al. [21] doped different rare earth metal elements into nickel ferrites oxides through the sol-gel citrate auto-combustion method to investigate its influence on optical and electrical transport properties. Liu et al. [22] added Ni into Cu-Al spinel as a catalyst for methanol steam reforming. They found that the addition of Ni can slow down the releasing rate of Cu and produce smaller Cu nanoparticles than pure Cu-Al spinel. Mn oxide has been investigated as an effective promoter for FTS catalysts, and some concerning researches revealed that a suitable amount of Mn could increase the dispersion of metallic Co due to the interaction of Co with Mn oxide [23–25], but excessive Mn would block the active sites of the catalysts and decrease the activity [26]. Salazar-Contreras et al. [23] added Mn into SiO2 and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) to promote Co-based FTS catalyst, and found that the activity of the catalyst was improved while the selectivity to olefins declined. Gao and co-workers [27] prepared LaCoxMn1-xO3 perovskites by sol-gel method as FTS catalysts and found that Mn-containing perovskites favored the formation of Co2C and improve the selectivity toward alcohols. Liu et al. [28] synthesized CoMn oxides through a one-pot synthesis method, which showed high CO conversion with high C2−4 olefins selectivity. Considering the promotional effect of Mn oxide and the good performance of 15Co/CoAl2O4, we synthesized Mn doped CoAl2O4 by sol-gel method to form defects on the surface of CoAl2O4 lattice and used it as support for Co based FTS catalyst to improve the dispersion of metal Co, so as to improve CO conversion as well as C5+ selectivity for FTS. We also compared the performance of Mn doping with impregnated Mn oxide, to investigate the role of lattice Mn in Co1-xMnxAl2O4 spinel played in the dispersion of loaded active Co, as well as its influence on the catalytic performance for conversion of syngas to C5+ paraffins. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of Mn-doped Co-Al spinel oxides: the method of synthesizing the spinel materials was referenced to a literature, to fabricate mesoporous spinel materials by a low-temperature sol-gel method [29]. For a specific preparation process, a certain amount of aluminum nitrate (Aladdin Co., Ltd. AR), cobalt nitrates (Aladdin Co., Ltd. AR) and manganese nitrate solution (50 wt.% of the aqueous solution, Aladdin Co., Ltd. AR) were mixed and dissolved in ethanol (Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. AR) at room temperature. The molar ratio of (Co + Mn) / Al was a constant value of 1/2, and the molar ratio of ethanol/Al was 50/1. After the precursors were dissolved in alcohol, a desirable amount of propylene oxide (Aladdin Co., Ltd. AR) was added to the obtained solution under a stirring condition at 303 K, and the molar ratio of propylene oxide/Al was 20/1. Then the gel would form in about 8 min. Heated the gel at 353 K in a water bath for 8 h, and then put the gel into an oven at 363 K overnight. The dried solid was then calcined at 1023 K for 5 h in air. The obtained supports with different Mn contents were prepared and marked as CMA-m, m represents the molar ratio of Co/Mn in the supports. For comparison, CoAl2O4 was also prepared by the same method and marked as CA. Furthermore, 1.5 Mn-CA was also prepared by conventional incipient wetness impregnation method to compare the properties of the loaded Mn oxide with the lattice Mn in CMA-m. In the preparation process of 1.5 Mn-CA, manganese nitrate was dissolved in distilled water and added into CA, then dried at 393 K for 12 h, and then calcined at 823 K for 6 h in static air atmosphere. The weight of Mn was 1.5 wt.% to the total weight of the support, which was the same as the content of Mn in CMA-20. Preparation of catalysts: catalysts were prepared by conventional incipient wetness impregnation technique. Cobalt nitrate was dissolved in distilled water and added into the supports, with the content of metal cobalt to be 15 wt.% to the total weight of the catalyst if not specified. The precursors of the catalysts were dried at 393 K for 12 h, and then calcined at 823 K for 6 h in static air atmosphere. The Co-loaded catalysts were marked as Co/CMA-m, Co/CA and Co/1.5 Mn-CA respectively, and 15Co/CMA-m means Co/CMA-m catalyst with a Co loading of 15 wt.%. 2.2 Catalyst testing The catalysts were tested in a fixed bed reactor. Approximately 1 mL of the catalysts diluted with 1 mL quartz sand were reduced at 723 K with flowing H2 with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2000 h−1 for 6 h. After reduction, syngas (H2/CO = 2:1) was fed into the reactor with a GHSV of 4000 h−1. The reaction was carried out at 498 K under the pressure of 3 MPa if not specified. The effluents were analyzed every 24 h to calculate CO conversion and product selectivity. The tail gas was analyzed on-line by an Agilent 7890A GC apparatus equipped with a TCD detector and a Plot Q packed column. An Agilent 7890A GC apparatus equipped with a FID detector and a HP-5 column was used to analyze the liquid products. The water phase of the liquid products was analyzed with sec-butyl alcohol as the internal standard. The wax sample was dissolved in CS2 and analyzed by an Agilent 7890A GC apparatus equipped with an FID and a stainless steel column (GSD-3). C5+ STY is the weight (g) of C5+ production produced by per kilogram of catalyst per hour. The conversion of CO was calculated by testing the molar content of CO in the feed gas and the tail gas. The selectivity was calculated by the follow formula: (1) S i = N i × n i ∑ ( N i × n i ) In which Si is the selectivity to product i (i: alkane, alkene, alcohol, CO2, etc.), Ni is the molar value of product i per hour, ni is the carbon number of product i. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction spectra (XRD) XRD analyses were carried out on a PANalytical X’Pert3 powder diffractometer with CuKα radiation. The reduced samples were reduced at 723 K for 6 h and passivated in air before analyses. The spent samples were washed by n-hexane and dried in Ar flow at 393 K for 6 to remove wax in the pores, and passivated in air before analyses. Approximately 100 mg of sample was packed in sample unit and recorded from 10° to 90° (2θ) at a scanning speed of 2°/min for three times. The relative crystallinity of CMA-m was calculated according to the following formula: (2) Dc = Am / A In which Dc is the relative crystallinity; Am is average XRD peak area of CMA-m of the three repeated XRD results and A is XRD peak area of CA of the three repeated XRD results. XRD patterns of reduced and spent catalysts were recorded and analyzed by X’pert High Score software with JCPDS library. In addition, diameters of the loaded Co nanoparticles of the catalysts were calculated by the following formula: (3) d (nm) = kλ / (Bcosθ) In this formula, k represents the Sherrer constant, λ is the wavelength of X-ray, B is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction peak, and θ is the angle of diffraction. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) EPR is used to detect the valence states and local chemical environment of paramagnetic species, and might be helpful to provide a detailed description of the bonding and orientation of a surface complex. In EPR experiments, a solid sample is placed in an external magnetic field that splits the energy levels (allowed spin states) of unpaired electron. In this work, EPR measurements at room temperature were carried out at the X-band (9.5 GHz) using a Bruker EMXplus spectrometer. N2 physisorption The specific surface area (BET surface area) and the porosity [30] of the supports and the fresh catalysts were tested by N2 physisorption method on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument. Typically, about 50 mg sample was packed in a quartz tube. After degassing at 423 K for 6 h, the sample was measured at N2 atmosphere and 77 K. High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) The morphology of the supports and the catalysts were displayed on a JEM-ARM200 F instrument in STEM mode at 300 KV. And energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were also tested using the same instrument. Before the characterization, the samples were uniformly dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonication. The sizes of supports and loaded cobalt were obtained by the average of more than 200 particles from different areas. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) Zeton Altramira AMI-300 instrument was employed to acquire the H2-TPR results. In details, approximately 100 mg of supports or fresh catalyst was packed in a U-type quartz tube. The sample was flushed with argon for 30 min at 393 K and cooled down to 323 K before testing. Then, the temperature was raised to 1073 K at a ramp of 10 K/min in 10 % H2/Ar. The results of H2 consumption were recorded by a TCD detector. Chemisorption Pulsed CO chemisorption were measured on the same instrument as H2-TPR. A U-type quartz tube was used to load approximately 200 mg of fresh catalyst, followed by reduction of the sample at 723 K for 6 h with 10 % H2/Ar. Before pulsed in CO, argon was flushed in and kept for 30 min to remove the physiosorbed H2. Pulsed CO chemisorption was tested at 323 K according to reference [26]. The quantity of desorbed CO was measured by TCD signal. The CO pulses was stopped until the signal was constant. H2 temperature program desorption (H2-TPD) H2-TPD was also tested with a Zeton Altramira AMI-300 instrument. Approximately 200 mg of fresh catalyst was loaded in a U-type quartz tube. The sample was first reduced at 723 K for 6 h, and then switched to argon to cool the temperature to 323 K. Pulsed H2 chemisorption was carried out at 323 K and stopped when the TCD signal was a constant. Then switched to argon and kept for 30 min to remove physiosorbed H2. H2-TPD were carried out from 323 K to 1073 K at a ramp of 10 K/min. The quantity of desorbed H2 was detected by TCD. It was assumed that H2 was dissociated on Co atom and the ratio of H/Co is 1 [31]. The dispersion (D) of Co was calculated by the quantity of desorbed H2 and the reduction degree of Co according to formula (4). And the particle size of cobalt can also be calculated according to the dispersion using formula (6) [30]: (4) D = [0.5893 × (μmol/g H2)] × 2/[%metal] × (reduction degree) (5) Reduction degree = [H2 consumption value] / ([%metal] / 3 × 4 / 58.94 × 10) (6) d (nm) = 96 / D In which the (%metal) is 15, which is the mass percentage of Co loaded on catalysts; H2 consumption value is calculated based on the reduction step of H2-TPD; Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra of supports were tested by a NanoWizard Ultra Speed & in Via Raman instrument with a helium-neon (He-Ne) wave laser (632 nm). The scanning range was from 100 to 1000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) Composition of supports was determined by ICP technique using a Perkin Elmer ICP-OES 7300DV equipment. The samples were fully digested in a microwave oven before testing. X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was measured with a Thermos Scientific Escalab 250Xi instrument using monochromatic Al Kα at 15 KV and 10.8 mA as an X-ray source to measure the surface electronic state of supports and catalysts. All the XPS spectra were corrected by referring to the binding energy of C1s at 284.5 eV. The surface atom ratios were calculated according to the follow formula: (7) n i n j = I i I j × σ j σ i × E k j 0.6 E k i 0.6 In which n, I, EK and σ represent for number of atoms, intensity, kinetic energy and photoionization cross section, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of supports 3.1.1 Crystalline phase of supports XRD patterns of CMA-m, CA and 1.5 Mn-CA are shown in Fig. 1 a-b, and 2θ of the standard peaks of CoAl2O4 (JCPDS card: 01–082–2248) and MnAl2O4 (2θ = 58.4°, JCPDS card: 00–029–0880) are marked on the horizontal axis in Fig. 1. As shown in Fig. 1a, the XRD diffraction peaks of all the supports are consistent with those of CoAl2O4. The partial enlarged view of XRD patterns in the range of 54° ∼ 61° are shown in Fig. 1b. Compared with CA, the diffraction peak of CMA-m at 59.3° shifts to lower angle when the content of Mn is high (m ≤ 8), approaching to MnAl2O4 (2θ = 58.4°, JCPDS card: 00–029–0880) (especially for CMA-1), indicating that Mn might dope into the lattice of spinel and form the Mn doping structure: Co1-xMnxAl2O4. The doping of Mn into the lattice of spinel might cause the change of the unit cell parameters and led to shift of the diffraction peak at 59.3°. However, when the content of Mn in CMA-m is low (m ≥ 12), the amount of unit cell containing lattice Mn might be too small to observe the peak shift. The crystallinities of CMA-m relative to CA were also calculated according to reference [32], and shown in Table 1 . With the increase of Mn content, the relative crystallinity of CMA-m decreases. For samples that Co/Mn is no less than 20, the relative crystallinity keeps higher than 90 %, while the relative crystallinity of CMA-1 drops down to 83.2 % due to the increase of Mn doping amount. Compared with CA, a slight decrease of the crystallinity of CMA-50 or CMA-20 might cause more defects on the surface of crystal grains, while the dramatic drop down of the crystallinity of CMA-1 means that, the influence of the amorphous phase in CMA-1 is non-negligible. And the crystallinity of supports has obvious influences on the dispersion of the loaded metal [33]. 3.1.2 Surface structure of supports In order to investigate the influence of lattice Mn doping on the structure of CoAl2O4, the supports were characterized by Raman spectra. CoAl2O4 belongs to the cubic crystal system with Fd3m space group (Z = 8) which has 5 kinds of Raman activity models: A1g (764 cm−1); F2g (644, 511 and 203 cm−1) and Eg (413 cm−1) [34]. The Raman spectra of CMA-m, 1.5 Mn-CA and CA are given in Fig. 2 , which shows that the Raman spectra of CMA-m are consistent with CA on the whole. The peak at 705 cm−1 (A1g) is attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration peak of CoO4 and AlO6; The peak at 615 cm−1 (F2g (3)) is attributed to the anti-symmetric stretching vibration peak of CoO4 and the bending vibration peak of CoO4 and AlO6; The peak at 525.5 cm−1 (F2g (2)) is attributed to the stretching vibration peak of CoO4; The peak at 406 cm−1 (Eg) belongs to the symmetrical bending vibration peak of CoO4; The peak at 201 cm−1(F2g (1)) belongs to the complete translational vibration peak of CoO4. Among them, F2g (2) is considered as the key evidence to judge the existence of AO bond in spinel [35]. Fig. 2b is the enlarged Raman spectra in the range of 475 ∼ 550 cm−1. As shown in Fig. 2b, the F2g (2) peak of CA locates at 525.5 cm−1, while the F2g (2) characteristic peaks of CMA-50, CMA-20 and CMA-1 locate at 525.3 cm−1, 523.5 cm−1 and 512.2 cm−1, respectively. It indicates that lattice Mn doping causes the redshift of F2g (2) peak, and the shift increases with the increase of Mn content. But compared with CMA-20, no redshift of F2g (2) peak could be observed on the spectrum of 1.5 Mn-CA. The ionic radius of Mn (0.67 Å) is larger than that of cobalt (0.59 Å), when Mn dopes into the lattice, the size of crystal cells containing Mn should be larger than others [36], so the stretching vibration frequency of MnO4 might be lower than that of CoO4. The F2g (2) peak wave number of CoAl2O4 is reported to be larger than that of MnAl2O4 [35], so the Raman spectra in Fig. 2 should be a further evidence besides XRD in Fig. 1 to verify that the doped Mn is in the lattice of CMA-m, mainly resides in the Td site of the spinel structure [20]. Fig. 2b also shows that compared with CA, the Raman spectrum of 1.5 Mn-CA containing the same percent of Mn as CMA-20 shows no observable Raman shift of the peak at 525.3 cm−1, indicating that Mn loaded with conventional impregnation method at the condition applied in this work cannot make it doped into the crystal lattice, the impregnated Mn oxides in 1.5 Mn-CA should locate on the surface of CA grains. The Raman shift of CMA-20 and 1.5 Mn-CA was obtained by Gauss-fitting with the R2 of 0.99, which is listed in Fig. S3. Otherwise, the signal peak of CMA-1 at 600 ∼ 700 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of MnO bond of MnO2 [37,38]. Due to the high content of Mn of CMA-1, the signal of MnO2 is strong and overlapped with the peaks of F2g (3) and A1g. The stronger MnO vibration signal at 600 ∼ 700 cm−1 for CMA-1 indicates that, in addition to the Mn doping into the crystal lattice in CMA-1, there is also a part of Mn that existed as the form of Mn oxide on the surface of crystal grains. However, the MnO2 signal couldn’t be detected in the XRD patterns in Fig. 1, indicating that the amount of MnO2 in CMA-1 should be low, or the dispersion of MnO2 is high. 3.1.3 Valence state and distribution of Mn in the supports Room temperature EPR was performed on CA, CMA-20, CMA-1 and 1.5 Mn/CA to determine the valence states and local chemical environment of Co and Mn ions in the spinel supports. The results are shown in Fig. 3 . Due to the fast spin relaxation, the EPR signal displayed a large line width of the CA support, which is consistent with the results in the literature [39]. Obvious six hyperfine lines appear in the CAM-20 sample as shown in Fig. 3b, which should be caused by the interaction between the spin of the electron (S = 5/2) and the nucleus (I = 5/2) of the Mn2+ ions. The g-factor (g) and the hyperfine coupling constant (A) are different when paramagnetic ions are in different chemical environments [40]. The EPR results of CMA-20 in Fig. 3b provide the g-factor (g = 1.992) and the hyperfine coupling constant (A = 98 G) for Mn2+ ions, which are similar to the simulation results (g = 1.979, A = 98 G) [20], indicating that paramagnetic Mn2+ ions entered into the structure of spinel and mainly located in the Td (tetradentate) position. As is shown in Fig. 3c, when the content of Mn is high (CMA-1), there is a larger line width signal overlays on the six hyperfine lines, caused by the mutual interaction of Mn paramagnetic centers [20], which means that besides isolated lattice Mn, there are also Mn oxides exist on CMA-1. According to the simulation results, the EPR spectra have no obvious hyperfine lines between 350 m T and 450 m T for Mn (IV) = O [40]. The EPR result of 1.5 Mn/CA in Fig. 3d shows that the hyperfine lines are very weak, which might be generated by a small amount of Mn (II). The EPR results indicates that the valence state of Mn in 1.5 Mn/CA are mainly Mn4+, which is different from CMA-20. The g-factor and the hyperfine coupling constant for 1.5 Mn/CA is 2.023 and 93 G, which is also different from CMA-20, indicating that the small amount of Mn (II) of 1.5 Mn/CA should not locate in Td position of spinel structure, they might locate at the boundary of spinel grains contacting with Mn oxide particles, or at the surface layer of Mn oxide particles, leading to their partial reduction or unsaturated coordination. 3.1.4 Elemental distribution of supports XPS and ICP tests were carried out to measure the elemental content of Mn and Co on the surface and in the bulk phase of the supports, to speculate the possible position of lattice Mn in crystal grains. As is shown in Table 2 , ICP results illustrate that the bulk Co(spinel)/Mn atomic ratio is consistent with the theoretical value. But it is interesting to note that, according to the XPS results in Table 2, the surface Co(spinel)/Mn atomic ratio is much smaller than the theoretical value, indicating that compared with the distribution of lattice Co, the lattice Mn tends to distribute in the surface layer of the supports. As mentioned above, the size of crystal cells containing Mn should be larger than others. So, according to the ICP and the XPS results, it is reasonable to speculate that, the expanding of the crystal cells containing lattice Mn would destroy the periodicity of the lattice structure, or end the growth of lattice at the position of -Al-O-Mn-O, and intends to form nanoscale defects such as steps, corners and concaves at the surface of crystal grains [20,36], to make most of the lattice Mn presented in the surface layer rather than in bulk phase. 3.1.5 Morphology of supports The morphologies of the supports were characterized by HRTEM and shows in Fig. 4 . It can be seen from Fig. 4a and 4e that the grain morphology of CA is relatively perfect. The two dimensional projections of the grains are generally hexagonal with clear boundaries and complete lattice fringe orientation. It means that the grains of CA are similar to single crystal of cubic crystal system with perfect crystal planes. While the HRTEM images of CMA-m in Fig. 4 show that, doping of Mn destroyed the crystalline integrity of the crystal grains, causing defects on the corners and edges of the crystal grains. The TEM images of CMA-20 in Fig. 4c and Fig. 4g clearly show that the boundary of grains is incomplete, while the lattice fringes in the grains are still complete, indicating that CMA-20 is mainly composed of single crystal grains, but many defects are formed on the surfaces or edges of grains. With the increase of the content of lattice Mn, as shown in Fig. 4d and h, the boundary of the CMA-1 grains become more disordered, and the lattice fringes are incomplete, which displayed the characteristics of polycrystalline grains with the formation of grain boundaries. According to the EDS-mapping of CMA-20 shown in Fig. 5 , lattice Mn tends to locate on the surface layer rather than the bulk phase in the crystal grains, which is consistent with the ICP and XPS results shown in Table 2, as a further evidence to indicate that Mn might be mainly located on the surface layer of the single crystal grain of CMA-20 to form nanoscale crystal defects such as steps, corners and concaves. Fig. 4i–m are statistical distribution diagrams of the particle size of supports. They show that lattice Mn displays no significant influence on the average particle size of the supports. However, the FWHM data obtained from the particle size statistical fitting curves in Fig. 4i–m indicate that the particle size distribution of the support gradually become wider with the increase of Mn content. As shown in Fig. 4a–h, the particle size of CA in Fig. 4a is very uniform, while the particle size of CMA-1 is obviously uneven. The increase of FWHM of the particle size distribution profiles and the change of the morphology vs Mn content are consistent with the change of crystallinities listed in Table 1 to verify that, for CMA-50 and CMA-20, a little Mn doping into the lattice of CA spinel would produce some defects on the single crystal grains with the grain size hardly changed, but a high Mn content would have a great influence on the crystal integrity of the spinel to form polycrystalline grains with irregular shapes, so that the particle size distribution of CMA-1 is significantly broadened. 3.1.6 Texture properties of supports Specific surface area, average pore size and total pore volume of the supports were determined by N2 physisorption method, and the results are listed in Table 3 . With the increase of Mn content, specific surface area of the supports increases due to the formation of more defects on the surface of grains, except CMA-50, the Mn content of which is too little to influence its specific surface area. A slight decrease of pore size is also observed for lattice Mn-doped spinels due to that, the incomplete edges and corners favored the close packing of the grains. So the data listed in Table 3 could also be taken as a circumstantial evidence to the formation of crystal defects on lattice Mn-doped samples. The surface area, average pore size and total pore volume were decreased after loading Co species. It is also interesting to note that, the change of average pore size caused by Co loading seems to be relating with the relative size of the loaded Co particle to the support grain, which would be discussed later, together with the data of Co particle sizes listed in Table 5. 3.2 Physicochemical properties of catalysts 3.2.1 Crystalline phase of catalysts XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts and the spent ones are shown in Fig. 6 a and Fig. 6b, respectively. According to the JCPDS card of CoAl2O4, the diffraction peaks of 2Theta at 45°, 55.6° and 59.2° correspond to the lattice planes of (400), (422) and (511) of CoAl2O4 respectively, while the peak of 2Theta at 44.2° correspond to the (111) lattice plane of fcc Co. XRD characterization results show that the diffraction peak position and relative strength of the peaks of reduced 15Co/CA, 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20, 15Co/CMA-1 and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA had no obvious change during reaction. This phenomenon indicates that the crystal structure of these catalysts didn’t change during reaction process. Based on the XRD patterns of Fig. 6, the particle sizes of Co (44.7°, peak of fcc Co overlapping with support) and supports (55.6° and 59.3°) of reduced and spent 15Co/CMA-20 were calculated by Scherer’s formula. The results are shown in Table S1. The particle sizes of Co and support show no obvious change during reaction. 3.2.2 Morphology of catalysts HAADF-STEM characterization was performed on reduced 15Co/CA, 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/CMA-1, and the cobalt metal particle size distribution of each catalyst was also statistically analyzed and shown in Fig. 7 . In the HRTEM images shown in Fig. 7e-h, the lattice fringe of 2.04 Å belongs to fcc Co (111) lattice plane. As seen from Fig. 7e, the lattice fringe of 4.68 Å belongs to CoAl2O4 (111) lattice plane, and in Fig. 7f, the displayed lattice fringe is 2.86 Å which belongs to the lattice plane of CoAl2O4 (220). In Fig. 7g, the lattice fringes belong to CoAl2O4 (222) and CoAl2O4 (311), while Fig. 7h shows the lattice fringes of CoAl2O4 (311) and CoAl2O4 (400). It is interesting to note that, with the increase of Mn content, the high-index lattice planes become to be more observable than the low-index ones. As is known, the high-index faceted metal oxides usually show higher surface energy and provide more active sites on its surface [41]. Therefore, the exposure of high-index lattice planes caused by Mn doping might lead to a higher dispersion of metal Co and higher metal-support interaction. In addition, none of the lattice fringes of Mn compounds could be observed. Fig. 7i-m show the statistics distribution diagrams of cobalt particle size calculated based on the HAADF-STEM images. The average Co particle size of 15Co/CA is the largest, approximately 10.9 nm, while those of 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/CMA-1 are 5.5 nm, 5.7 nm and 6.3 nm respectively, which are all significantly smaller than the Co particle size of 15Co/CA. 3.2.3 Reduction properties of catalysts The reducibility of the supports and the catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR method and shown in Fig. S4 and Fig. 8 respectively. As shown in Fig. S4, no obvious hydrogen consumption peak could be observed during the reduction process of CA, CMA-20 and 1.5 Mn-CA below 950 K, but an obvious hydrogen consumption peak in the range of 540 ∼ 665 K was observed during the reduction of CMA-1. The reduction temperature of Mn4+/Mn3+to Mn2+ is in the range of 500 ∼ 650 K according to references [42,43]. It’s speculated that the hydrogen consumption peak of CMA-1 in Fig. S4 at 500 ∼ 650 K is attributed to the reduction peak of MnO2, which is consistent with the Raman characterization results, implying that there is a small amount of MnO2 existing on the surface of the supports, even though most of Mn atoms in CMA-1 are doped into the lattice. In the TPR profile of 1.5 Mn-CA given in Fig. S4, no hydrogen consumption peak at 500 ∼ 650 K is found due to the low content of Mn on 1.5 Mn-CA. In Fig. 8, the reduction profiles mainly show three reduction peaks. The peak at 580 ∼ 720 K is the reduction peak of Co3O4 to CoO, and the reduction of CoO to Co0 usually occurs at 720 ∼ 1000 K [44]. H2 consumption above 950 K corresponds to the reduction of cobalt in spinel lattice [11]. Compared with 15Co/CA, no signal of MnO2 reduction is found in the TPR profiles of 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, which is consistent with the support reduction profiles. For 15Co/CMA-1, there is an obvious hydrogen consumption peak at 540 K belonging to the reduction peak of MnO2, which also occurs during the reduction of CMA-1 as shown in Fig. S4. Compared with 15Co/CA, the initial reduction temperature of Co3O4 to CoO on 15Co/CMA-m is lower than 15Co/CA, while the initial reduction temperature of 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA is similar with 15Co/CA. The difference of the initial reduction temperature is supposed to be affected by the particle size of cobalt on catalysts [45]. As shown in Fig. 7 and Table 5, the cobalt sizes of 15Co/CMA-m are obviously smaller than 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, which might lead to their lower initial reduction temperature, but the reduction temperature of CoO to Co0 on 15Co/CMA-m or 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA is higher than that of 15Co/CA, and it gradually increases with the increase of Mn content, indicating that the presence of Mn inhibited the reduction of CoO to Co0. 3.2.4 H2 uptake of catalysts Data of H2 adsorption values and reduction degrees obtained by H2-TPD are listed in Table 4 , which show that the reduction degrees for 15Co/CMA-m are obviously lower than that of 15Co/CA (81.4 %). The reduction degree for 15Co/CMA-20 is 36.4 %, which is even lower than 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA (48.1 %), as a supplementary evidence to TPR to indicate that, the presence of Mn inhibits the reduction of Co species to Co0, and the influence of lattice Mn on the reducibility of Co species is more obvious than impregnated Mn. According to H2 adsorption pyrolysis model on the surface of metal cobalt, without considering the impact of H2 spillover to the support, the hydrogen adsorption value on the surface of metal cobalt represents the amount of surface Co0 [24], which is the active sites participating in H2 adsorption and activation steps during the reaction. H2 adsorption ability also influences the competitive adsorption of other co-reactant on the catalyst surface, such as CO in FTS process. Table 4 shows that, the H2 adsorption value of 15Co/CMA-50 is 107.4 μmol/g-cat., slightly higher than 15Co/CA (99.7 μmol/g-cat.), which might result from the smaller Co0 particle size of 15Co/CMA-50. It means that higher Co dispersion of 15Co/CMA-50 than 15Co/CA has greater influence on H2 adsorption capability than the influence of the lower reducibility. Further increasing the lattice Mn content leads to the obvious decrease of H2 adsorption value. For 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/CMA-1, the H2 adsorption values are 77.5 μmol/g-cat. and 74.0 μmol/g-cat. respectively, which means that, a further decrease of Co reducibility has more influences than Co dispersion on H2 adsorption capability. The H2 adsorption value of 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA is 70.9 μmol/g-cat., lower than that of 15Co/CMA-20 with the same Mn content, which might result from the larger Co0 particle size, i.e. lower Co dispersion of 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA. 3.2.5 CO uptake of catalysts CO adsorption ability is another key parameter to measure the performance of FTS catalysts [11]. As given in Table 4, the CO adsorption values of 15Co/CMA-50 and 15Co/CMA-20 are 55.5 μmol/g-cat. and 63.5 μmol/g-cat. respectively, which are obviously higher than 15Co/CA (49.4 μmol/g-cat.), but it is noteworthy that the CO adsorption value of 15Co/CMA-1 is only 37.5 μmol/g-cat., which is much lower than 15Co/CA, and also lower than 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA (42.9 μmol/g-cat.). It is difficult to explain the phenomenon mentioned above according to the reducibility or Co0 particle size data of the catalysts. But considering the poor crystallinity and the larger amount of Mn oxide existing on 15Co/CMA-1 than 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA observed according to the Raman and TPR results, it might be reasonable to suppose that, the influence of lattice Mn in spinel crystal might absolutely different from that of Mn oxide on CO adsorption over Co site. Lattice Mn in spinel crystal might lead to the interaction of spinel grain with the loaded Co to be favorable for CO adsorption, but the interaction of Mn oxide with the loaded Co might be unfavorable for CO adsorption. Data in Table 4 show that lattice Mn doping had an important influence on the adsorption of CO and H2. It is known that the ratio of H2/CO adsorption amount might act as an effective factor to represent the situation of competitive adsorption of H2 and CO in FTS process to influence the H*/C* ratio on the surface of catalyst, which would further influence the catalytic performance [24,26,46]. According to the adsorption data given in Table 4, it is easy to calculate that the H2/CO adsorption value ratio of 15Co/CMA-20 is 1.22, which is obviously lower than 15Co/CA (1.97) and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA (1.65). A lower H2/CO adsorption value ratio means a comparatively stronger CO adsorption capacity than H2 on active Co site, which would influence product selectivity of FTS process. 3.2.6 Dispersion of Co nanoparticles According to the dispersion results given in Table 4, Co0 dispersion of 15Co/CA, 9.6 %, is the lowest among the investigated catalysts. Co0 dispersion of the lattice Mn-doped samples, 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/CMA-1, are 15.3 %, 16.7 % and 14.8 % respectively, indicating that lattice Mn doping could significantly improve the dispersion of the loaded Co0. 15Co/CMA-20 has the highest dispersion. The Co0 dispersion of 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA is 11.7 %, a little higher than 15Co/CA, but obviously lower than 15Co/CMA-m, indicating that, although the impregnated Mn oxide could slightly improve Co0 dispersion, but the influence of lattice Mn doping on Co0 dispersion is much more effective than the impregnated Mn oxide. According to the TPR curve of CMA-1 in Fig. S4, the mass fraction of MnO2 on the surface of CMA-1 is calculated to be about 5.0 wt.% of the total mass of the support. The catalyst with the same mass fraction of Mn oxide was prepared by the same impregnation method as 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, and marked as 15Co/5 Mn-CA, to investigate the effect of MnO2 on Co0 dispersion for 15Co/CMA-1, and the result is listed in Table S2. As Table S2 shown, the Co0 dispersion of 15Co/5 Mn-CA is 11.7 %, indicating that the higher Co0 dispersion of 15Co/CMA-1 than 15Co/CA is mainly due to the existence of lattice Mn, and the lower Co0 dispersion of 15Co/CMA-1 than 15Co/CMA-20 might result from the existence of Mn oxide. The average particle sizes of Co0 are obtained based on Co0 dispersion, XRD and TEM methods, and list in Table 5. The particle sizes of Co0 obtained by different methods are similar, indicating that the dispersion and the particle sizes of Co0 calculated based on Co dispersion are reliable. The results in Table 5 show that, compared with 15Co/CA, lattice Mn doping could significantly reduce the particle size of Co0. The particle size of Co0 of 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA catalyst is also smaller than 15Co/CA, but larger than 15Co/ CMA-20. It is also noted that, according to Table 3, the amounts of average pore size reduction caused by Co loading are 0.1 nm, 2.6 nm, 1.0 nm and 0.7 nm for CA, CMA-50, CMA-20 and CMA-1 respectively, while the ratio of particle size of Co based on data by H2-TPD listed in Table 5 to the pore size of support of the four corresponding catalysts are 1.02, 0.75, 0.74 and 1.05 respectively. The data show that, for 15Co/CA or 15Co/CMA-1, the particle size of Co is close to the pore size of support, and the amount of average pore size reduction caused by Co loading is smaller than the case of 15Co/CMA-50 or 15Co/CMA-20. It means that when the particle size of Co is close to the pore size of support, it intends to locate at the outer surface of the porthole to block up part of the pores of the support, while smaller Co particles of 15Co/CMA-50 or 15Co/CMA-20 would favor part of loaded Co located in the pores of support. 3.2.7 Surface valence state of catalysts XPS results of reduced 15Co/CA, 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20, 15Co/CMA-1 and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA are shown in Fig. S5 and Table 6 , respectively. As the XPS spectra show in Fig. S5a, the peaks at the binding energies of 782.0 ± 0.1 eV and 802.2 ± 0.1 eV correspond to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 signals of Co2+ (spinel) in the spinel structure. The binding energies of Co2+ (loaded) are 780.5 ± 0.1 eV and 795.9 ± 0.2 eV. The Co2+ (loaded) binding energy of 15Co/CMA-m are almost the same as 15Co/CA, indicating that the influence of lattice Mn or impregnated Mn oxide on the electronic state of loaded cobalt is difficult to observe by XPS. The XPS spectra of Mn 2p is showed in Fig. S5b. According to the reference, the binding energies of MnO, Mn2O3 and MnO2 are 641.2 eV, 641.8 eV and 642.2 eV, respectively. Fig. S5b shows that Mn 2p3/2 mainly has two peaks: 642.2 eV and 640.7 eV, which should correspond to Mn4+ and Mn3+/Mn2+ respectively. The existence of Mn3+/Mn2+ in 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/CMA-50 might result from the partial reduction of terminal Mn-O bands in lattice sites exposed to the surface of Mn-doped spinel grains. The surface Co2+ (loaded)/Al and Mn/Al ratios of reduced catalysts are listed in Table 6. Compared with 15Co/CA (surface Co2+ (loaded)/Al = 0.10), a suitable amount of Mn doping increases the surface Co2+ (loaded)/Al ratio for 15Co/CMA-50 (0.14) and 15Co/CMA-20 (0.14) for the reason that it increases the dispersion of Co2+ (loaded). According to the surface Co2+ (loaded)/Al ratio (0.10) and Mn/Al ratio (0.10) of 15Co/CMA-1, the lower surface Co2+ (loaded)/Al ratio than 15Co/CMA-50 and 15Co/CMA-20 should be due to the existence of distinct amount of MnOx on its surface. In addition, the lower surface Co2+ (loaded)/Al ratio (0.08) of 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA than 15Co/CMA-20 might result from its lower Co0 dispersion. 3.3 Catalytic performance FTS catalytic performances of 15Co/CA, 15Co/CMA-m and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA were tested under the reaction conditions of: T = 498 K, P = 3 MPa, n (H2)/n (CO) = 2, the feed gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 4000 h−1. The results are listed in Table 7 . CO conversion rate of 15Co/CA, 15Co/CMA-50, 15Co/CMA-20 and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA are 174.0 mmol/gCo h 175.6 mmol/gCo h 218.7 mmol/gCo h and 197.9 mmol/gCo h with C5+ selectivity to be 74.1 %, 75.9 %, 79.9 % and 70.8 % respectively. 15Co/CMA-20 shows the best activity and C5+ selectivity among the tested catalysts, while 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, containing the same Mn content as 15Co/CMA-20, shows a lower C5+ selectivity and a similar activity with 15Co/CA, indicating that Mn doping into lattice has an obviously better influence on catalytic performance than that of the impregnated Mn species. CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity on 15Co/CMA-1 are 62.0 mmol/gCo h and 33.1 % respectively, with the highest selectivity to C2−4 (53.9 %) among the tested catalysts. In addition, it is worth noting that, the higher CO conversion on 15Co/CMA-20 would lead to a higher partial pressure of steam than the cases of 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA when they were all tested at the same reaction conditions. The effect of water in FTS has been well-documented that play a key role in FTS kinetics [47]. So, in order to eliminate the influence of partial pressure of steam when comparing the performance of 15Co/CMA-20 with 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, 15Co/CMA-20 was also tested at GHSV of 4500 h−1 to obtain a similar CO conversion (40 % ∼ 50 %) to 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA that tested at GHSV of 4000 h−1, and the results are also shown in Table 7. CO conversion on 15Co/CMA-20 is 47.2 %, C5+ STY is 302.5 g C5+/ kg-cat. h and C5+ selectivity is 78.7 % when tested at GHSV of 4500 h−1, implying that 15Co/CMA-20 is more active and especially more selective towards C5+ than 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA when at similar partial pressure of steam. Performance of 20Co0.15Ru/Al2O3 catalyst supported on Al2O3-sasol as a typical FTS catalyst support is cited from literature [48] and listed in Table 7 as a reference to show that, the performance of 15Co/CMA-20 is equivalent to a typical FTS catalyst for industrial application. Stability for FTS reaction was tested on 23Co/CMA-20 catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . It shows that the decline of CO conversion is less than 5% during the 1200 h testing, indicating its good stability [49–51]. 3.4 Discussion XRD, Raman, EPR and TEM results of lattice Mn-doped CMA-m spinels show that, compared with CA, Mn doping in the lattice sites of spinel destroyed the periodicity growth of crystal, and formed defects on crystal grains, which might cause more attachment points such as nanoscale concaves, steps and corners on the surface of supports. Dispersion and particle size data in Tables 4 and 5 show that, compared with 15Co/CA with a Co0 particle size of 10.0 nm, the particle size of Co0 on 15Co/CMA-m reduce to 6.0 ± 0.5 nm, and the dispersion of Co0 on 15Co/CMA-m could be significantly improved, indicating that the lattice defects caused by lattice Mn doping could distinctly improve the dispersion of metal cobalt. For 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, although impregnating Mn on the surface of CA could also decrease the Co0 particle size, but compared with 15Co/CMA-20 with the same mass fraction of Mn, the dispersion of Co0 on 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA is lower, indicating that lattice Mn doping is more effective to improve the dispersion of metallic cobalt than impregnated Mn oxide. It is further verified by the characterization and FTS test results that, lattice Mn doping changes the physicochemical properties of the supports and the catalysts, leading to the difference of the catalytic performance. HAADF-STEM images show that more high index crystal planes are exposed on 15Co/CMA-m than 15Co/CA, and the stronger surface energy of high index crystal planes might cause stronger metal-support interaction, which would influence the reduction of loaded Co species. TPR results show that the reduction of loaded Co species to Co0 requires a higher temperature than that on 15Co/CA when Co was loaded on Mn-doped CMA-m supports. However, it is noteworthy that the CO adsorption capabilities of 15Co/CMA-50 and 15Co/CMA-20 are obviously higher than 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, which means that lattice Mn in CMA-m spinel structure favored the adsorption and activation of CO on the catalyst, but impregnated Mn oxide shows no positive effect on CO adsorption. The higher CO adsorption capability of 15Co/CMA-50 and 15Co/CMA-20 might be caused by the promoting effect of the highly dispersed Co0 and the lattice Mn-doping of CMA-m grain. FTS results show that CO adsorption capability has a key influence on the improvement of CO conversion and C5+ selectivity. CO conversions and C5+ selectivity on 15Co/CMA-50 and 15Co/CMA-20 are obviously higher than 15Co/CA and 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA, while C5+ selectivity on 15Co/1.5 Mn-CA is lower than 15Co/CA. The FTS reaction results verify that the influence of lattice Mn is absolutely different from the impregnated Mn oxide on the properties and catalytic performance of CoAl2O4 spinel supported Co based FTS catalyst. The 1200 h running results of FTS reaction performed on Co/CMA-20 catalyst show that, the catalyst is stable and exhibits a good potential industrial application prospect for FTS process, and the good stability of CMA might make it a potential material for application in some other processes that have a high requirement for hydrothermal stability as in FTS process. 4 Conclusion A series of lattice Mn-doped cobalt-aluminum spinel materials (CMA-m) were prepared by sol-gel method, and evaluated as supports for FTS reaction. Lattice Mn doping led to lattice distortion of the support, and generated obvious defects on the surface of the crystal grains, thereby providing more attachment sites for cobalt loading. The dispersion of cobalt loaded on CMA-m were obviously higher than that loaded on CA or Mn-CA which contained Mn oxide species impregnated on CA. Lattice Mn doping distinctly improved the CO adsorption capacity of 15Co/CMA-50 and 15Co/CMA-20 catalysts with suitable lattice Mn content, which led to higher CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity for FTS reaction. 15Co/CMA-20 catalyst with a Co (spinel)/Mn ratio of 20 showed the highest activity and C5+ selectivity. The lattice Mn in the spinel grains showed absolutely different influence from the impregnated Mn oxide on the properties and performance of cobalt-aluminum spinel supported Co based FTS catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Mn-doped spinel oxides CoAl2O4 marked as CMA-m (m = Co/Mn atom ratio) herein were synthesized and evaluated for the first time as supports of Co-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts. HAADF-STEM images showed that Mn doping caused more crystal defects on the surface of CMA-m grains, which may provide more attachment sites for cobalt loading, leading to much smaller Co0 particle size of 15Co/CMA-m than that of 15Co/CoAl2O4. Data of H2/CO chemisorption showed that the interaction of highly dispersed Co0 with lattice Mn-doped CMA-m grain has a promotive effect on CO adsorption capability. FTS evaluation results demonstrate that 15Co/CMA-20 showed the highest CO conversion, C5+ selectivity and C5+ STY, benefiting from its high Co0 dispersion and CO chemisorption capability as a result of suitable Mn doping into the lattice of CoAl2O4, which was confirmed very different from the influence of impregnated Mn oxide over CoAl2O4.
coredata.dc:title: Mn doping of Co-Al spinel as Fischer-Tropsch catalyst support
